title: Harsh 1–2 Shift / Jerky Upshifts
symptom_short: Hard shift when going 1–2 or during upshifts

likely_causes.cause: Low/old transmission fluid or wrong fluid type
likely_causes.notes: Most common; wrong fluid causes pressure/shift issues.

likely_causes.cause: Adaptive shift strategy needs relearn (after battery/TCM reset)
likely_causes.notes: Often after battery disconnect or repair.

likely_causes.cause: Shift solenoid sticking / valve body wear
Engine/Transmission mount worn causing clunk
likely_causes.notes: Feels like a bang but actually drivetrain movement.

recommended_checks: Check for transmission fluid level/condition (follow correct procedure; some are sealed).
Scan for transmission-related codes (P07xx) and check live data if possible.
Note if harsh shift happens only when cold vs always.
Inspect mounts for cracks or excessive movement.
safety_warning: Repeated harsh shifting can accelerate internal wear. Avoid aggressive driving until diagnosed.

title: Delayed Engagement into Drive or Reverse
symptom_short: Delay before moving after shifting to D or R

likely_causes.cause: Low transmission fluid level due to leak
likely_causes.notes: Air in hydraulic circuits causes delay.

likely_causes.cause: Worn internal clutches / pump wear
Valve body pressure control issue / solenoid fault

recommended_checks: Look under vehicle for red/brown fluid leaks.
Check fluid level/condition per OEM procedure.
Scan for codes; note if delay is worse when hot.
safety_warning: Driving with low fluid can destroy the transmission quickly. If engagement becomes very delayed, avoid driving.

title: Transmission Slipping (RPM Flare) Under Acceleration
symptom_short: RPM rises but speed does not increase properly

likely_causes.cause: Low/overheated transmission fluid
Worn clutch packs / bands
likely_causes.notes: Often progressive and worse under load.

likely_causes.cause: Torque converter clutch or internal pressure loss
likely_causes.notes: May have shudder or lockup issues.

recommended_checks: Check for burnt smell and dark fluid (if accessible).
Scan for slip/ratio codes (P0730–P0736) and TCC codes (P0740–P0744).
Stop towing/heavy load until resolved.
safety_warning: Continued driving while slipping can rapidly burn clutches and require full rebuild.

title: No Reverse (Automatic)
symptom_short: Reverse does not engage but forward gears may work

likely_causes.cause: Low transmission fluid / internal leak
Reverse clutch/band failure
Valve body / solenoid control fault

recommended_checks: Check fluid level/condition and scan for codes.
Confirm shift linkage/cable is selecting Reverse properly.
Avoid repeatedly revving in Reverse—causes more damage.
safety_warning: Do not rev the engine trying to force reverse. If reverse is gone, professional diagnosis is needed.

title: Stuck in One Gear / Limp Mode (Automatic)
symptom_short: Limited gears, sluggish, may start in 2nd/3rd only

likely_causes.cause: Transmission solenoid / pressure control fault
TCM/PCM issue or low system voltage
Internal mechanical failure detected by ratio monitoring

recommended_checks: Scan codes from TCM (not just engine ECU).
Check battery/charging voltage and related fuses.
Let transmission cool and see if behavior changes.
safety_warning: Avoid highway driving if limited to one gear. Limp mode is protective; don’t ignore it.

title: Torque Converter Shudder at 45–60 mph
symptom_short: Vibration/shudder during light cruise, often in lockup

likely_causes.cause: Degraded transmission fluid / wrong friction modifiers
likely_causes.notes: Often improved with proper fluid service.

likely_causes.cause: TCC solenoid or valve body wear
Torque converter clutch lining wear

recommended_checks: Confirm symptom occurs during light throttle cruise and disappears when you slightly accelerate or shift manually.
Scan for TCC-related codes and monitor slip RPM data if possible.
Check for any engine misfire (misfire can mimic shudder).
safety_warning: Prolonged shudder can contaminate fluid and damage valve body. Avoid long highway trips until diagnosed.

title: Red/Brown Fluid Leak Under Vehicle
symptom_short: Transmission fluid leak spots after parking

likely_causes.cause: Pan gasket seepage or loose pan bolts
Axle seal / output seal leak
Cooler line leak / radiator transmission cooler leak

recommended_checks: Check leak location: front (bellhousing), middle (pan), sides (axle), front grille area (cooler lines).
Measure fluid level ASAP if procedure allows.
Do not drive far if leak is active.
safety_warning: Low transmission fluid can lead to sudden loss of drive and expensive damage. If leaking heavily, tow is safer.

title: CVT ‘Rubber Band’ Feel / High RPM with Slow Acceleration
symptom_short: Engine revs high but acceleration feels delayed/soft

likely_causes.cause: Normal CVT behavior under certain throttle
likely_causes.notes: Some CVTs hold RPM for efficiency.

likely_causes.cause: CVT fluid degraded or wrong fluid
likely_causes.notes: CVT is sensitive to fluid spec.

likely_causes.cause: CVT belt/chain wear or pulley issues
likely_causes.notes: May show whine or ratio codes.

recommended_checks: Check service history: CVT fluid interval is critical.
Scan for CVT ratio/pressure codes (varies by manufacturer).
Listen for whine that changes with speed.
safety_warning: If the symptom is getting worse quickly or accompanied by whining/burning smell, avoid driving to prevent major CVT damage.

title: CVT Overheat Warning / Limp Mode When Hot
symptom_short: Warning message, reduced power after heat buildup

likely_causes.cause: Low CVT fluid level / leak
likely_causes.notes: Heat rises fast when fluid low.

likely_causes.cause: CVT cooler restriction or cooling fan issue
Internal CVT wear generating excess heat

recommended_checks: Stop, let it cool, and avoid aggressive driving.
Inspect for leaks and check cooler lines if accessible.
Scan TCM for temperature-related codes/data.
safety_warning: Overheated CVT fluid can permanently damage belts and pulleys. If warning repeats, get professional inspection.

title: DCT/DSG Shudder at Low Speed / Takeoff
symptom_short: Shudder/jerk in stop-and-go, especially when taking off

likely_causes.cause: Normal DCT characteristics in slow crawling
Clutch adaptation needed / software update
Clutch pack wear / mechatronics issue
likely_causes.notes: May have fault codes and harsh engagement.

recommended_checks: Check if symptom is worse when hot and in traffic.
Scan for DCT/Mechatronics codes and clutch adaptation values.
Avoid creeping on throttle—use deliberate takeoffs if safe.
safety_warning: Excessive creeping can overheat DCT clutches. If warning lights appear, stop and cool down.

title: Manual Clutch Slipping + Burnt Smell
symptom_short: RPM rises without speed increase, burnt odor

likely_causes.cause: Worn clutch disc/pressure plate
likely_causes.notes: Most common; worsens quickly under load.

likely_causes.cause: Oil contamination on clutch (rear main seal leak)
likely_causes.notes: Leak can ruin new clutch if not fixed.

likely_causes.cause: Hydraulic clutch partially engaged (master/slave issue)

recommended_checks: Test slip: in a higher gear at low speed, accelerate and watch RPM vs speed.
Inspect for engine/trans oil leaks near bellhousing.
Check clutch pedal feel and engagement point.
safety_warning: A slipping clutch can fail suddenly, leaving you unable to move. Avoid towing and hard acceleration.

title: Grinding When Shifting into Gear (Manual)

likely_causes.cause: Clutch not fully disengaging (hydraulic issue, worn clutch)
Worn synchronizers (synchro wear)
likely_causes.notes: Often one gear worse than others.

likely_causes.cause: Low or wrong gear oil

recommended_checks: Check clutch pedal free play and fluid level (if hydraulic).
Try shifting with engine off (if easier, clutch disengagement suspected).
Inspect for leaks around master/slave cylinder.
safety_warning: Forcing gears can damage synchronizers and gears. Fix clutch/hydraulics first.

title: Whining Noise that Changes with Vehicle Speed
symptom_short: Whine/hum varies with speed (not engine RPM)

likely_causes.cause: Low fluid level causing pump or bearing noise
Bearing wear (input/output/differential)
Not transmission: wheel bearing or tire noise

recommended_checks: Note if noise changes when you turn left/right (wheel bearing clue).
Check fluid level/condition if possible.
Scan for codes if drivability issues also present.
safety_warning: If noise becomes loud suddenly or you feel vibration + loss of drive, stop driving and tow.

title: Transmission Overheating During Towing / Hills
symptom_short: Overheat warning or burnt smell when towing or climbing

likely_causes.cause: Fluid degraded / low level
Cooler restriction / failed fan / blocked radiator fins
TCC not locking properly generating extra heat

recommended_checks: Stop and cool down; do not keep pushing when overheated.
Inspect cooler lines and radiator area for blockage.
Avoid towing until fluid/cooling system is verified.
safety_warning: Overheated transmission fluid can lead to sudden failure. If warning persists, tow is safer than driving.

title: Shifter Position Mismatch (PRNDL) / Won’t Start in Park
symptom_short: Shifter says Park but car acts like Neutral (or won’t start)

likely_causes.cause: Transmission range sensor / neutral safety switch fault
Shift cable/linkage misadjusted or worn
Low voltage affecting module readings

recommended_checks: Try starting in Neutral (N) as a test (if safe).
Scan for P0705 and check range sensor data if possible.
Inspect shifter cable bushings and adjustment.
safety_warning: If the vehicle can start in gear, it’s a serious safety hazard. Fix immediately.

title: Incorrect Gear Ratio Codes (P0730–P0736)
symptom_short: Ratio codes, slipping, harsh shifts, limp mode possible

likely_causes.cause: Low fluid / pressure loss
Internal clutch/band wear
Speed sensor issues (input/output speed sensor)

recommended_checks: Check fluid level/condition; note any burnt smell.
Scan TCM and confirm if speed sensor signals look correct.
If ratio code + slip present, reduce driving immediately.
safety_warning: Ratio codes often indicate internal slip. Continued driving can turn a repair into a full rebuild.

title: P0700 — Transmission Control System Malfunction
symptom_short: P0700 in engine ECU indicates TCM has stored faults

likely_causes.cause: TCM has specific stored codes (solenoid, pressure, ratio, sensor)
likely_causes.notes: P0700 is a flag, not root cause.

likely_causes.cause: Wiring/connector issues to TCM
likely_causes.notes: Water intrusion common in some vehicles.

recommended_checks: Read codes from the transmission module (TCM) specifically.
Inspect transmission harness connectors for corrosion.
Check battery/charging health; low voltage can trigger module faults.
safety_warning: If accompanied by limp mode or slipping, reduce driving and diagnose quickly.
